title: NetHack
data:
[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[NetHack](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NetHack "wikipedia:NetHack")***

[![](/images/thumb/e/ec/NetHack-Logo.svg/250px-NetHack-Logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:NetHack-Logo.svg)



Official NetHack logo

- *This article is about the culture, development, and historic aspects of NetHack. For information on how to play the game and a start to the game mechanics, see [Guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook").*

***NetHack*** is a [roguelike](/wiki/Roguelike "Roguelike") computer game, and the most famous and popular of its kind. The latest version is 3.6.7, released on February 16, 2023. *NetHack* can be downloaded at the [official *NetHack* download page](https://www.nethack.org/v367/downloads.html). It is also available in [other languages](/wiki/NetHack_in_other_languages "NetHack in other languages"). Many [variants](/wiki/Variant "Variant") and [patches](/wiki/NetHack_Patch_Database "NetHack Patch Database") are also available.

The phrase "vanilla *NetHack*" refers to the latest version as it was released by the [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam"), without any additional [patches](/wiki/Patch "Patch").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Screenshots](#Screenshots)

- [2 Why do people like *NetHack*?](#Why_do_people_like_NetHack.3F)

- [3 Graphical user interfaces](#Graphical_user_interfaces)

- [4 Title](#Title)

- [5 Popular culture](#Popular_culture)

- [6 History](#History)

- [7 Download](#Download)

  - [7.1 Official version](#Official_version)
  - [7.2 Server platforms](#Server_platforms)
  - [7.3 Desktop platforms](#Desktop_platforms)
  - [7.4 Handset platforms](#Handset_platforms)
  - [7.5 Other interfaces](#Other_interfaces)
  - [7.6 Other languages](#Other_languages)

- [8 External links](#External_links)

## Why do people like *NetHack*?

- *This page is a **[stub](/wiki/Category:Stubs "Category:Stubs")**. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by [**expanding this page**.](https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=NetHack\&action=edit)*

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"I think this page should be a kind of FAQ, as it may be the first place strangers will visit upon seeing the Main Page."*

*NetHack* enjoys popularity in niches. Mathematicians, programmers, physicists, engineers, linguists and writers all feel a strong pull, though anyone with an eye for detail, a sense of completeness, a respect for complexity, and a head for numbers will be at home.

On the surface, the game is a hack'n'slash [Dungeons and Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_and_Dragons "Dungeons and Dragons") clone, but its subtle sense of humor and intellectual rigor elevate it from the faintly nerdy to the sharply geeky.

Just as a mathematician seeks elegant expressions over fuzzy generalities, *NetHack* eschews graphics in favor of perfectly crafted, well-defined [ASCII](/wiki/ASCII "ASCII") characters. While other games are dated by their interfaces, *NetHack* is preserved in ascetic purity.

The programmer is drawn to *NetHack* as an extension of the operating system. Its culture is deeply intertwined with that of the Unix systems, and indeed is a staple fixture on any good [Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") system - a known quantity, ageless, familiar, and soothing; whatever hairy command-line tasks are required, *nethack(6)* is always there.

*NetHack* is hard: while other games can be completed in an afternoon, you may go years without finishing *NetHack*.

*NetHack* is unforgiving: if you die, you stay dead. There is no save-and-reload crutch here. Put simply, *NetHack* is a harsh mistress, whose respect you must earn. In time, you learn to respect it back.

*NetHack* is deep: in your first game, you will die quickly, and come back worrying about how to survive. You will learn, eventually, and move onto higher concerns. You will stop worrying about your score, and start considering questions of optimality, efficiency, and elegance. You will consult tables and guides in search of an edge because everyone knows the best way to have fun in a game is to take 20 until you beat an impossible DC, rather than try to actually succeed at something hard yet possible. You may dive into the very [source code](/wiki/Source_code "Source code"), looking to explain that one-in-a-thousand shot you just pulled off. You will probably learn some C, and possibly get into heated debates about the merits of pseudorandom number generators, expected returns, inconsistencies between competing mythologies, and the ethics of exploiting bugs.

*NetHack* is history: Descending from *[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue_\(game\) "Rogue (game)")*, *NetHack* has 39 years of development behind it. It is one of the few computer games widely played by people who are younger than it. From this history arises a kind of authority.

## Graphical user interfaces

- *Main article: [Graphical user interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface")*

As well as the standard [ASCII](/wiki/ASCII "ASCII") interface, many official and unofficial [graphical user interfaces](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface") are available. Using a graphical interface allows the game to be played with [tiles](/wiki/Tiles "Tiles") instead of ASCII graphics. The best known are probably the officially supported ports for Windows, Mac and Linux:

- [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows") (the standard NetHackW\.exe available from nethack.org, or available on the Windows Store)
- [Qt](/wiki/Qt "Qt") for Linux and Mac
- [X11](/wiki/X11 "X11") for Linux (and Mac if developer tools are installed)

Notable unofficial graphical interfaces are:

- Web terminals, allowing the player to play on a public server with either ASCII graphics or tiles in their browser without downloading anything. Available on [NAO](/wiki/NAO "NAO") and [Hardfought](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought").
- [NetHack for Android](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface#NetHack_Android "Graphical user interface")
- [iNetHack](/wiki/INetHack "INetHack") for iOS
- [Falcon's Eye](/wiki/Falcon%27s_Eye "Falcon's Eye") and [Vulture](/wiki/Vulture "Vulture"), offering a 3D isometric view of the map. Note that neither of these is supported anymore.

## Title

The title is properly spelled "NetHack", with two capital letters. "nethack" is also correct when used to refer to the name of the game binary. "Nethack" is a common misspelling, even having been used by members of the [DevTeam](/wiki/DevTeam "DevTeam") in comments in the [source code](/wiki/Source_code "Source code").

## Popular culture

- *This page is a **[stub](/wiki/Category:Stubs "Category:Stubs")**. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by [**expanding this page**.](https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=NetHack\&action=edit)*

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Gads this begs to be longer."*

In its legacy, *NetHack* has directly and indirectly been referenced in many sources.

- [*NetHack* quotes](http://bash.org/?search=nethack\&sort=0\&show=25), on the Bash Quote Database.
- The game *Deus Ex* has [a reference to beating a future version of *NetHack*](http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=108920764) in the distant future.
- [Dudley's Dungeon](/wiki/Dudley%27s_Dungeon "Dudley's Dungeon"), a webcomic set in *NetHack*.
- [*Dungeons of Dredmor*](http://www.dungeonsofdredmor.com) is a newer, sprite animated dungeon crawler with a more in-your-face sense of humor that nonetheless feels almost like a GUI rewrite of *NetHack*, and features direct quotes from *NetHack* like "You hear the sounds of a cash register."
- In the game [*FreedroidRPG*](http://www.freedroid.org/), you can play an ultra-simplified version of *NetHack* as a game-within-a-game (much easier to beat than actual *NetHack*).
- The [Screen terminal emulator](http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=screen.git;a=blob;f=src/attacher.c#l609) has idiosyncratic messages from *NetHack*, such as "Suddenly, the dungeon collapses." when the program crashes.
- The game [*Spelunky*](http://spelunkyworld.com/), which has some similarities to *NetHack* and is inspired by classic roguelikes, dungeon crawlers, and adventure games including *NetHack*, has *NetHack* references such as Vlad, his tower, and the camera.

## History

- *Main article: [Game history](/wiki/Game_history "Game history")*

*NetHack'*s first version, [1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"), was released in July 1987, descending directly from [Jay Fenlason](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack") and [Andries Brouwer](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0")'s Hack. Subsequent early versions of *NetHack*, namely [1.4f](/wiki/NetHack_1.4f "NetHack 1.4f"), [2.2a](/wiki/NetHack_2.2a "NetHack 2.2a") and [2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e") were released through 1987 and 1988.

In 1989, the first release of *NetHack'*s current incarnation, [3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), was posted to Usenet. It featured a massive expansion over the previous versions.

[*NetHack* 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0") was released in 1993, bringing several big changes, such as the introduction of [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") in place of [Hell](/wiki/Hell "Hell"), and the introduction of the [invocation ritual](/wiki/Invocation_ritual "Invocation ritual").

Three years later, [*NetHack* 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0") was released, dedicated to the memory of [Izchak Miller](/wiki/Izchak_Miller "Izchak Miller").

Several forks of *NetHack* were produced through the lifespan of both 3.1 and 3.2. The current version is [3.6.6](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.6 "NetHack 3.6.6"), but [3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") continues to be popular considering that it was the only version available for a long time.

In addition, many [variants](/wiki/Variant "Variant") that are much more open about their development, such as [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") or [NetHack 4](/wiki/NetHack_4 "NetHack 4"), are popular.

## Download

- *For downloading the wiki itself, see [NetHackWiki:Download](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Download "NetHackWiki:Download").*

### Official version

- [Official *NetHack* download page](https://www.nethack.org/common/index.html) (Tiles and text interfaces are available for Windows, Linux, Mac, and other systems)

### Server platforms

- Terminal telnet and SSH servers, such as:

  - [nethack.alt.org](/wiki/NAO "NAO")
  - [hardfought.org](/wiki/Hardfought "Hardfought")
  - [em.slashem.me](https://em.slashem.me/)
  - Any of the other servers listed in the [public server](/wiki/Public_server "Public server") article

- [NetHax, an internet browser version of *NetHack* created in Ajax](http://www.big-ape.net/nethax/)

- [nethack-nacl, *NetHack* 3.4.3 for Google Native Client (NaCl)](https://github.com/kaladron/nethack-nacl)

### Desktop platforms

- [*NetHack* Patch Database](http://bilious.alt.org/)
- [*NetHack* RPMs for Linux](http://rpmfind.net/linux/rpm2html/search.php?query=nethack)
- [Atari Binaries](http://www.cs.tu-berlin.de/~gaston/nethack)
- [NetBSD packages](ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/packages/pkgsrc/games/README.html)
- [*NetHack* for RISC OS](http://www.phlamethrower.co.uk/riscos/nethack.php)
- [*NetHack* 3.4.1 packages for RedHat on S/390](ftp://ftp.linux.org.uk/pub/linux/alan/Packages/S390-games/)
- [*NetHack* 3.1.2 for Windows NT 4.0 MIPS](http://vpsland.superglobalmegacorp.com/install/WindowsNT4.0-MIPS/games/nethack-3.1.2-MIPS.zip)
- [Old to ancient versions of *Hack* and *NetHack* for MS-DOS](ftp://ftp.sunet.se/pub/games/nethack/Msdos/NH_older)

### Handset platforms

- [*iNetHack* for iOS](/wiki/INetHack "INetHack") on App Store
- [*NetHack* for Android](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.tbd.NetHack) by gurr
- [*NetHack* for Android](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nethackff) by Fredrik Franstrom
- [*NetHackDS* for Nintendo DS](https://github.com/fancypantalons/NetHack/releases)
- [*NetHack* for PSP](http://www.feelthepawa.com/PSP/Nethack/)
- [*NetHack* 3.3.1 for Agenda VR3](http://www.delorie.com/agenda/nethack/download.html)
- [*NetHack* for Psion 5/5MX](http://www.suttoncourtenay.org.uk/duncan/Downloads)
- [*NetHack* 3.4.3 for Windows CE 2.11 x86](http://vpsland.superglobalmegacorp.com/install/WindowsCE/nethack/nethack3.4.3-WinCE-2.11-x86.zip)

### Other interfaces

- *Main article: [Graphical user interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface")*

* [Vulture, a 3D display for *NetHack* 3.4.3](http://www.darkarts.co.za/vulture-for-nethack) (see also [Vulture](/wiki/Vulture "Vulture"))
* [noegnud, alternate UI system for *NetHack*](http://www.darkarts.co.za/noegnud) (see also [noegnud](/wiki/Noegnud "Noegnud"))
* [*NetHack* for gtk2](http://gtk2hack.sourceforge.net/download.html) the window system
* [glHack](http://glhack.sourceforge.net/download.php) (see also [glHack](/wiki/GlHack "GlHack"))
* [*NetHack* 3D](http://www.sbrain.org/nethack3d/)

### Other languages

- *Main article: [NetHack in other languages](/wiki/NetHack_in_other_languages "NetHack in other languages")*

* [*NetHack* in Japanese, based on *NetHack* 3.4.3](http://jnethack.sourceforge.jp/)
* [Other variants, Japanese translation](http://nethack-users.sourceforge.jp/)
* [NetHack-De, *NetHack* in German](http://sourceforge.net/projects/nethack-de/files/) (work in progress)
* [NetzHack, *NetHack* in German](http://www.netzhack.de/download/neuste/)
* [*NetHack* 3.4.3 in Spanish](http://spanish-nethack.sourceforge.net/)

## External links

- [Official *NetHack* site](https://www.nethack.org/)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.2. Click here for more information.](/images/b/b5/Nh362-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.2. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-362}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
NetHack

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Wikipedia has an article about:
NetHack
Official NetHack logo
This article is about the culture, development, and historic aspects of NetHack. For information on how to play the game and a start to the game mechanics, see Guidebook.

NetHack is a roguelike computer game, and the most famous and popular of its kind. The latest version is 3.6.7, released on February 16, 2023. NetHack can be downloaded at the official NetHack download page. It is also available in other languages. Many variants and patches are also available.

The phrase "vanilla NetHack" refers to the latest version as it was released by the DevTeam, without any additional patches.

Contents

  • 2 Why do people like NetHack?
  • 3 Graphical user interfaces
  • 4 Title
  • 5 Popular culture
  • 6 History

Why do people like NetHack?

This page is a stub. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by expanding this page.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"I think this page should be a kind of FAQ, as it may be the first place strangers will visit upon seeing the Main Page."

NetHack enjoys popularity in niches. Mathematicians, programmers, physicists, engineers, linguists and writers all feel a strong pull, though anyone with an eye for detail, a sense of completeness, a respect for complexity, and a head for numbers will be at home.

On the surface, the game is a hack'n'slash Dungeons and Dragons clone, but its subtle sense of humor and intellectual rigor elevate it from the faintly nerdy to the sharply geeky.

Just as a mathematician seeks elegant expressions over fuzzy generalities, NetHack eschews graphics in favor of perfectly crafted, well-defined ASCII characters. While other games are dated by their interfaces, NetHack is preserved in ascetic purity.

The programmer is drawn to NetHack as an extension of the operating system. Its culture is deeply intertwined with that of the Unix systems, and indeed is a staple fixture on any good Unix system - a known quantity, ageless, familiar, and soothing; whatever hairy command-line tasks are required, nethack(6) is always there.

NetHack is hard: while other games can be completed in an afternoon, you may go years without finishing NetHack.

NetHack is unforgiving: if you die, you stay dead. There is no save-and-reload crutch here. Put simply, NetHack is a harsh mistress, whose respect you must earn. In time, you learn to respect it back.

NetHack is deep: in your first game, you will die quickly, and come back worrying about how to survive. You will learn, eventually, and move onto higher concerns. You will stop worrying about your score, and start considering questions of optimality, efficiency, and elegance. You will consult tables and guides in search of an edge because everyone knows the best way to have fun in a game is to take 20 until you beat an impossible DC, rather than try to actually succeed at something hard yet possible. You may dive into the very source code, looking to explain that one-in-a-thousand shot you just pulled off. You will probably learn some C, and possibly get into heated debates about the merits of pseudorandom number generators, expected returns, inconsistencies between competing mythologies, and the ethics of exploiting bugs.

NetHack is history: Descending from Rogue, NetHack has 39 years of development behind it. It is one of the few computer games widely played by people who are younger than it. From this history arises a kind of authority.

Graphical user interfaces

Main article: Graphical user interface

As well as the standard ASCII interface, many official and unofficial graphical user interfaces are available. Using a graphical interface allows the game to be played with tiles instead of ASCII graphics. The best known are probably the officially supported ports for Windows, Mac and Linux:

  • Microsoft Windows (the standard NetHackW.exe available from nethack.org, or available on the Windows Store)
  • Qt for Linux and Mac
  • X11 for Linux (and Mac if developer tools are installed)

Notable unofficial graphical interfaces are:

  • Web terminals, allowing the player to play on a public server with either ASCII graphics or tiles in their browser without downloading anything. Available on NAO and Hardfought.
  • NetHack for Android
  • iNetHack for iOS
  • Falcon's Eye and Vulture, offering a 3D isometric view of the map. Note that neither of these is supported anymore.

Title

The title is properly spelled "NetHack", with two capital letters. "nethack" is also correct when used to refer to the name of the game binary. "Nethack" is a common misspelling, even having been used by members of the DevTeam in comments in the source code.

Popular culture

This page is a stub. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by expanding this page.

"Gads this begs to be longer."

In its legacy, NetHack has directly and indirectly been referenced in many sources.

  • NetHack quotes, on the Bash Quote Database.
  • The game Deus Ex has a reference to beating a future version of NetHack in the distant future.
  • Dudley's Dungeon, a webcomic set in NetHack.
  • Dungeons of Dredmor is a newer, sprite animated dungeon crawler with a more in-your-face sense of humor that nonetheless feels almost like a GUI rewrite of NetHack, and features direct quotes from NetHack like "You hear the sounds of a cash register."
  • In the game FreedroidRPG, you can play an ultra-simplified version of NetHack as a game-within-a-game (much easier to beat than actual NetHack).
  • The Screen terminal emulator has idiosyncratic messages from NetHack, such as "Suddenly, the dungeon collapses." when the program crashes.
  • The game Spelunky, which has some similarities to NetHack and is inspired by classic roguelikes, dungeon crawlers, and adventure games including NetHack, has NetHack references such as Vlad, his tower, and the camera.

History

Main article: Game history

NetHack's first version, 1.3d, was released in July 1987, descending directly from Jay Fenlason and Andries Brouwer's Hack. Subsequent early versions of NetHack, namely 1.4f, 2.2a and 2.3e were released through 1987 and 1988.

In 1989, the first release of NetHack's current incarnation, 3.0.0, was posted to Usenet. It featured a massive expansion over the previous versions.

NetHack 3.1.0 was released in 1993, bringing several big changes, such as the introduction of Gehennom in place of Hell, and the introduction of the invocation ritual.

Three years later, NetHack 3.2.0 was released, dedicated to the memory of Izchak Miller.

Several forks of NetHack were produced through the lifespan of both 3.1 and 3.2. The current version is 3.6.6, but 3.4.3 continues to be popular considering that it was the only version available for a long time.

In addition, many variants that are much more open about their development, such as UnNetHack or NetHack 4, are popular.

Download

For downloading the wiki itself, see NetHackWiki:Download.

Official version

  • Official NetHack download page (Tiles and text interfaces are available for Windows, Linux, Mac, and other systems)

Server platforms

  • Terminal telnet and SSH servers, such as:
    • nethack.alt.org
    • hardfought.org
    • em.slashem.me
    • Any of the other servers listed in the public server article
  • NetHax, an internet browser version of NetHack created in Ajax
  • nethack-nacl, NetHack 3.4.3 for Google Native Client (NaCl)

Desktop platforms

  • NetHack Patch Database
  • NetHack RPMs for Linux
  • Atari Binaries
  • NetBSD packages
  • NetHack for RISC OS
  • NetHack 3.4.1 packages for RedHat on S/390
  • NetHack 3.1.2 for Windows NT 4.0 MIPS
  • Old to ancient versions of Hack and NetHack for MS-DOS

Handset platforms

  • iNetHack for iOS on App Store
  • NetHack for Android by gurr
  • NetHack for Android by Fredrik Franstrom
  • NetHackDS for Nintendo DS
  • NetHack for PSP
  • NetHack 3.3.1 for Agenda VR3
  • NetHack for Psion 5/5MX
  • NetHack 3.4.3 for Windows CE 2.11 x86

Other interfaces

Main article: Graphical user interface
  • Vulture, a 3D display for NetHack 3.4.3 (see also Vulture)
  • noegnud, alternate UI system for NetHack (see also noegnud)
  • NetHack for gtk2 the window system
  • glHack (see also glHack)
  • NetHack 3D

Other languages

Main article: NetHack in other languages
  • NetHack in Japanese, based on NetHack 3.4.3
  • Other variants, Japanese translation
  • NetHack-De, NetHack in German (work in progress)
  • NetzHack, NetHack in German
  • NetHack 3.4.3 in Spanish

External links

  • Official NetHack site

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.2. Information on this page may be out of date.

rawPage:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''NetHack''}}
{{wikipedia|NetHack}}
[[File:NetHack-Logo.svg|thumb|250px|Official NetHack logo]]
{{otheruses|the culture, development, and historic aspects of NetHack|information on how to play the game and a start to the game mechanics|Guidebook}}

'''''NetHack''''' is a [[roguelike]] computer game, and the most famous and popular of its kind. The latest version is 3.6.7, released on February 16, 2023. ''NetHack'' can be downloaded at the [https://www.nethack.org/v367/downloads.html official ''NetHack'' download page]. It is also available in [[NetHack in other languages|other languages]].  Many [[variant]]s and [[NetHack Patch Database|patches]] are also available.

The phrase "vanilla ''NetHack''" refers to the latest version as it was released by the [[DevTeam]], without any additional [[patch]]es.

==Screenshots==
<gallery>
File:Nh343-vt-normal.png|Text-mode
File:Nh343-vt-ibmgraphics.png|Text-mode, with special characters
File:Win32screenshot.PNG|Tile-mode on Windows
</gallery>

{{random ttymap}}

==Why do people like ''NetHack''?==
{{stub|I think this page should be a kind of FAQ, as it may be the first place strangers will visit upon seeing the Main Page.}}

''NetHack'' enjoys popularity in niches. Mathematicians, programmers, physicists, engineers, linguists and writers all feel a strong pull, though anyone with an eye for detail, a sense of completeness, a respect for complexity, and a head for numbers will be at home.

On the surface, the game is a hack'n'slash [[Dungeons and Dragons]] clone, but its subtle sense of humor and intellectual rigor elevate it from the faintly nerdy to the sharply geeky.

Just as a mathematician seeks elegant expressions over fuzzy generalities, ''NetHack'' eschews graphics in favor of perfectly crafted, well-defined [[ASCII]] characters. While other games are dated by their interfaces, ''NetHack'' is preserved in ascetic purity.

The programmer is drawn to ''NetHack'' as an extension of the operating system. Its culture is deeply intertwined with that of the Unix systems, and indeed is a staple fixture on any good [[Unix]] system - a known quantity, ageless, familiar, and soothing; whatever hairy command-line tasks are required, ''nethack(6)'' is always there.

''NetHack'' is hard: while other games can be completed in an afternoon, you may go years without finishing ''NetHack''.

''NetHack'' is unforgiving: if you die, you stay dead. There is no save-and-reload crutch here. Put simply, ''NetHack'' is a harsh mistress, whose respect you must earn. In time, you learn to respect it back.

''NetHack'' is deep: in your first game, you will die quickly, and come back worrying about how to survive. You will learn, eventually, and move onto higher concerns. You will stop worrying about your score, and start considering questions of optimality, efficiency, and elegance. You will consult tables and guides in search of an edge because everyone knows the best way to have fun in a game is to take 20 until you beat an impossible DC, rather than try to actually succeed at something hard yet possible. You may dive into the very [[source code]], looking to explain that one-in-a-thousand shot you just pulled off. You will probably learn some C, and possibly get into heated debates about the merits of pseudorandom number generators, expected returns, inconsistencies between competing mythologies, and the ethics of exploiting bugs.

''NetHack'' is history: Descending from ''[[Rogue (game)|Rogue]]'', ''NetHack'' has {{#expr:({{CURRENTYEAR}}) - 1985}} years of development behind it. It is one of the few computer games widely played by people who are younger than it. From this history arises a kind of authority.

==Graphical user interfaces==
{{main|Graphical user interface}}

As well as the standard [[ASCII]] interface, many official and unofficial [[graphical user interface]]s are available. Using a graphical interface allows the game to be played with [[tiles]] instead of ASCII graphics. The best known are probably the officially supported ports for Windows, Mac and Linux:
* [[Microsoft Windows]] (the standard NetHackW.exe available from nethack.org, or available on the Windows Store)
* [[Qt]] for Linux and Mac
* [[X11]] for Linux (and Mac if developer tools are installed)

Notable unofficial graphical interfaces are:
* Web terminals, allowing the player to play on a public server with either ASCII graphics or tiles in their browser without downloading anything. Available on [[NAO]] and [[Hardfought]].
* [[Graphical user interface#NetHack Android|NetHack for Android]]
* [[iNetHack]] for iOS
* [[Falcon's Eye]] and [[Vulture]], offering a 3D isometric view of the map. Note that neither of these is supported anymore.

==Title==
The title is properly spelled "NetHack", with two capital letters. "nethack" is also correct when used to refer to the name of the game binary. "Nethack" is a common misspelling, even having been used by members of the [[DevTeam]] in comments in the [[source code]].

==Popular culture==
{{stub|Gads this begs to be longer.}}

In its legacy, ''NetHack'' has directly and indirectly been referenced in many sources.

* [http://bash.org/?search=nethack&sort=0&show=25 ''NetHack'' quotes], on the Bash Quote Database.
* The game ''Deus Ex'' has [http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=108920764 a reference to beating a future version of ''NetHack''] in the distant future.
* [[Dudley's Dungeon]], a webcomic set in ''NetHack''.
* [http://www.dungeonsofdredmor.com ''Dungeons of Dredmor''] is a newer, sprite animated dungeon crawler with a more in-your-face sense of humor that nonetheless feels almost like a GUI rewrite of ''NetHack'', and features direct quotes from ''NetHack'' like "You hear the sounds of a cash register."
* In the game [http://www.freedroid.org/ ''FreedroidRPG''], you can play an ultra-simplified version of ''NetHack'' as a game-within-a-game (much easier to beat than actual ''NetHack'').
* The [http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=screen.git;a=blob;f=src/attacher.c#l609 Screen terminal emulator] has idiosyncratic messages from ''NetHack'', such as "Suddenly, the dungeon collapses." when the program crashes.
* The game [http://spelunkyworld.com/ ''Spelunky''], which has some similarities to ''NetHack'' and is inspired by classic roguelikes, dungeon crawlers, and adventure games including ''NetHack'', has ''NetHack'' references such as Vlad, his tower, and the camera.

==History==
{{main|Game history}}

''NetHack'''s first version, [[NetHack 1.3d|1.3d]], was released in July 1987, descending directly from [[Jay Fenlason's Hack|Jay Fenlason]] and [[Hack 1.0|Andries Brouwer]]'s Hack. Subsequent early versions of ''NetHack'', namely [[NetHack 1.4f|1.4f]], [[NetHack 2.2a|2.2a]] and [[NetHack 2.3e|2.3e]] were released through 1987 and 1988.

In 1989, the first release of ''NetHack'''s current incarnation, [[NetHack 3.0.0|3.0.0]], was posted to Usenet. It featured a massive expansion over the previous versions.

[[NetHack 3.1.0|''NetHack'' 3.1.0]] was released in 1993, bringing several big changes, such as the introduction of [[Gehennom]] in place of [[Hell]], and the introduction of the [[invocation ritual]].

Three years later, [[NetHack 3.2.0|''NetHack'' 3.2.0]] was released, dedicated to the memory of [[Izchak Miller]].

Several forks of ''NetHack'' were produced through the lifespan of both 3.1 and 3.2. The current version is [[NetHack 3.6.6|3.6.6]], but [[NetHack 3.4.3|3.4.3]] continues to be popular considering that it was the only version available for a long time.

In addition, many [[variant]]s that are much more open about their development, such as [[UnNetHack]] or [[NetHack 4]], are popular.
